I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Gansu Urban Infrastructure Development and 
Wetland Protection Project.1 
 
2.  The project aims to promote socioeconomic development and improve the environment 
in Dingxi and Zhangye, two second-tier cities in Gansu Province of the PRC. It will support the 
rehabilitation and construction of urban infrastructure including roads, bridges, a water supply 
plant, water supply networks, sewerage and stormwater networks; the strengthening of urban 
management capacity in project cities; and wetland protection and management in Zhangye.2  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  The economic development of the western region of the PRC lags because of the harsh 
climate, underdeveloped transport and urban infrastructure, and lack of investment. Located in 
the northwestern part of the PRC, Gansu is one of the poorest provinces, with a provincial gross 
domestic product per capita ranked second-to-last among all the PRC provinces, autonomous 
regions, and municipalities. The urban poverty rate of 9.5% and the rural poverty rate of 20.6% 
make the province a priority area for development investment. Low per capita gross domestic 
products rank the cities of Dingxi and Zhangye 12th and 8th, respectively, among the 14 cities 
of Gansu. Dingxi’s urban poverty rate of 15.4% and Zhangye’s rate of 15.1% are almost two-
thirds more severe than the provincial average. The government launched the National Strategy 
for Development of the West to stimulate economic development and raise living standards.3 
The main pillars of the strategy are investing in urban infrastructure, protecting the environment, 
and attracting private investment in the region’s economy. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
has actively supported the strategy by providing technical assistance and financial resources to 
improve urban infrastructure for transportation, communication, power, and water resources; 
improve the environment; and support inclusive economic growth. The proposed project will 
complement  other  ADB-financed  projects  that  aim  to  improve  urban  infrastructure  and 
environment in the region.  
 
4.  Dingxi has a population of 2.7 million and is located 100 kilometers (km) southeast of 
Lanzhou, the capital of Gansu Province. An unfavorable climate that causes scarce water 
resources, frequent droughts, and short vegetation and construction periods combines with 
undeveloped  transport,  urban  infrastructure,  and  industry  to  hinder  the  city’s  economic 
development. Its 2011 per capita disposable income of CNY10,790 was well below the national 
average  of  CNY19,909  and  the  provincial  average  of  CNY13,118.  To  stimulate  economic 
growth and reduce poverty in the city, the government has developed a city development 
strategy that positions Dingxi as a transportation hub, includes the construction of a railway line 
and highways, and emphasizes the development of industrial zones and urban infrastructure.  
 
5.  Zhangye has a population of 1.2 million and is located in the middle of Gansu Province 
on the historic Silk Road. In 2011, the per capita disposable income of the urban population was

CNY10,855, well below the national and provincial averages. The city has recently experienced 
rapid population growth and faces a growing challenge to balance urban development and 
environmental protection. Water resources are declining because of their unsustainable use for 
agriculture and the rising population and industrial production, which degrades natural wetlands 
in the municipality. Promoting wetland protection and sustainable management, in combination 
with environmentally friendly urban infrastructure development, are priority goals for the city. 
The city’s rich historical and cultural background provides enormous potential for tourism. As the 
city master plan positions Zhangye as an environmentally friendly and livable city, the municipal 
government has started phasing out polluting industries, expanding the capacity of the city 
wastewater  treatment  plant,  relocating  an  industrial  zone  away  from  the  wetlands,  and 
promoting  ecotourism.  Both  project  cities  face  urban  development  challenges  including 
inadequate  urban  infrastructure,  the  low  quality  of  municipal  services,  and  the  lack  of 
institutional capacity.4 They require further assistance to stimulate economic growth.  
 
6.  Strategic fit. The project supports environmentally sustainable and inclusive economic 
growth, which is a key priority of ADB’s Strategy 2020.5 It aligns with ADB’s PRC country 
partnership strategy, 2011–2015, which supports the government's strategic goal of building an 
economically  developed  society  by  helping  to  foster  inclusive  growth  and  promoting 
environmental  sustainability.6 It  is  consistent  with  the  ADB  Urban  Operational  Plan,  which 
fosters competitive, green, and inclusive cities.7 The project supports Millennium Development 
Goal 7 by reducing biodiversity and habitat loss, providing sustainable access to safe drinking 
water and wastewater collection and treatment services, and improving the urban environment 
and transport services. It aligns with ADB’s Sustainable Transport Initiative for urban road 
components  and  related  institutional  capacity  development  in  public  transport,  traffic 
management, and urban transport management and safety.8 The project supports the PRC’s 
Twelfth  Five-Year  Plan,  2011–2015  and  2020  City  Master  Plans  for  project  cities,  which 
prioritize  economic  development,  environmental  protection,  and  ecologically  friendly 
urbanization. 
 
7.  Sector experience. This is the third ADB-financed urban development project in Gansu 
Province. Project design reflects lessons from previous ADB-financed urban development and 
wetland protection projects in the PRC. Urban development interventions require thoroughly 
planned urban development strategies and approaches accompanied by capacity building to 
strengthen sustainable and ecofriendly urban planning and management. Recent ADB reviews 
on reviving and protecting wetlands suggest that wetland protection and management in the 
PRC require intensive policy dialogue; sustainable financing from government budgets; and 
institutional capacity building in wetland protection, restoration, management, monitoring, and 
public education.9 
 
8.  Demonstration features. The project has the following demonstration features:  
 
(i)   Wetland  protection,  restoration,  and  management.  Natural  wetlands  in 
Zhangye  have  been  declining  rapidly  because  of  uncontrolled  urbanization, 
irrational land use for cultivation, and pollution. The project will contribute to the

(ii)  Urban  transport  oriented  toward  non-motorized  traffic,  public  transport, 
and  improved  urban  road  safety. The project will promote urban transport 
management  oriented  to  accommodate  pedestrian  and  bicycle  traffic,  public 
transport  services  with  bay  bus  stops,  improved  urban  traffic  control  and 
management,  and  pedestrian  and  traffic  safety.  It  will  include  a  program  to 
improve  urban  road  safety  that  encompasses an  urban  road  safety  audit  to 
identify road safety issues and recommend how to improve urban road safety in 
the project cities. Road safety improvement will be part of urban road engineering 
design, a public awareness program, and a program to improve the enforcement 
of traffic safety laws and regulations.  
 
(iii)  Stormwater management and wetland protection. New urban development is 
encroaching on the upper reaches of the ZNWP, into which urban surface runoff 
and  groundwater  will  be  discharged.  The  project  will  help  the  municipality 
establish  a  system  to  control  stormwater  pollution,  including  surface  runoff 
treatment prior to discharge into wetlands. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact will be socioeconomic development and improved environment in Dingxi and 
Zhangye.  The  outcome  will  be  the  improved  urban  infrastructure,  municipal  services,  and 
environment in Dingxi and Zhangye cities. The proposed components will provide much-needed 
assistance in environmental protection and local social and economic development. 
 
C.  Outputs 
10.  The project has four outputs:  
 
(i)  Improved  urban  infrastructure  operating  in  Dingxi.  This  component  will 
upgrade 1 road and construct 6 roads with a total length of 13.6 km and their 
associated facilities, including 5 bridges and 30 culverts, 22.3 km of storm water 
pipeline,  11.3  km  of  sewer  pipeline,  street  lighting,  landscaping,  and  traffic 
management facilities. All roads will have on both sides, sidewalks and lanes for 
non-motorized traffic. 
 
(ii)  Improved  urban  infrastructure  operating  in  Zhangye.  This  component 
includes the construction of 21 urban roads with a total length of 39.7 km, a new 
water supply plant, 49.2 km of piping network, and 49.6 km of sanitary piping 
network connected to the existing wastewater treatment plant.  
 
(iii)  Restored  and  protected  wetland  in  Zhangye.  This component  covers the 
ZNWP and other wetlands adjacent to the city and has three subcomponents: (a) 
wetland  protection  with  the  construction  of  four  protection  stations;  a  center 
combining  police,  patrol,  research,  monitoring,  and  education  facilities; 
watchtowers; park boundary demarcation; associated equipment for all services; 
and  a  comprehensive  education  and  capacity-building  program;  (b)  wetland 
restoration, comprising the restoration of 1,400 hectares (ha) of wetland and

4 
woodland habitats in the park and the planting of native and naturalized plant 
species; and (c) sustainable wetland utilization, comprising activities designed to 
promote sustainable ecotourism and public education in the park.  
 
(iv)  Project management and capacity development. This component will help the 
project cities develop and implement advanced project management systems 
and enhance capacity in urban planning and management. It will include capacity 
building  and  training  in  urban  planning  and  management,  environmental 
management, public transport and non-motorized traffic planning and safety, and 
storm water pollution control. A comprehensive capacity-building and training 
program  will  educate  the  public  on  wetland  protection  and  restoration  and 
enhance  the  wetland  management  and  monitoring  capacity  of  the  wetland 
management agency in Zhangye.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
16.  The project will benefit 941,000 people in Dingxi and Zhangye, of whom 15.6% are poor, 
by improving living conditions and the quality of municipal services and urban transport systems, 
with the emphasis on pedestrian and other non-motorized modes of transport, and by facilitating 
more environmentally and ecologically friendly urban development.  
 
A.  Technical 
17.  The project’s urban infrastructure components will construct and upgrade urban roads 
and bridges; a water supply plant; stormwater, drainage, and sanitary sewerage networks; and 
street lighting, providing landscaping and urban open spaces. Detailed engineering design will 
align with up-to-date urban design standards and specifications and international best practices. 
For the urban road subcomponents, a people-centric design concept has been incorporated 
with special emphasis on planning and facilities for safe pedestrian and bicycle traffic and public 
transport. Sanitary piping networks will significantly increase sewer coverage in the project cities 
and improve the urban living environment. The wetland protection component will help balance 
urban  development  and  environmental  protection  in  Zhangye  by  restoring  and  protecting 
wetland  habitats  and  supporting  the  development  of  ecotourism.  A  detailed  description  of 
components is in the PAM (footnote 10). 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
18.  Economic  analysis  evaluated  technical  options  and  confirmed  that  the  project 
components are designed using the least-cost options to support the cities’ long-term urban 
development plans. The project’s economic internal rate of return is 15.7%. The subproject 
economic internal rate of return is computed at 15.5% for Dingxi urban infrastructure, 15.7% for 
Zhangye urban infrastructure, 16.3% for Zhangye water supply, and 15.8% for Zhangye wetland 
protection—all of which exceed the economic opportunity cost of capital of 12.0%. The results 
are robust under the normal range of sensitivity analyses. Economic costs include (i) capital 
costs, including land acquisition, resettlement, and environmental mitigation and monitoring; (ii) 
project  management  and  institutional  strengthening;  (iii)  physical  contingencies;  and  (iv) 
operation  and  maintenance.  Economic  benefits  identified  for  the  urban  infrastructure 
components include (i) savings in vehicle operating costs, (ii) time savings, (iii) accident cost 
reductions, and (iv) emission reductions. Economic benefits identified for the wetland protection 
component include (i) arrested wetland area shrinkage and deterioration, (ii) reduced pollution, 
(iii) irrigation water savings on farmland adjacent to wetlands, and (iv) reduced flood risk. 
Benefits that cannot be readily quantified, such as improved health and increased employment, 
were not included.12 
 
19.  Financial cost–benefit analysis of the revenue-generating water supply plant and piping 
network confirmed the financial viability of these subcomponents. The financial cost–benefit 
analysis, undertaken on an incremental basis, concluded that the financial internal rate of return, 
calculated at 9.3% discount rate, exceeds after tax the 2.6% weighted average cost of capital by 
an adequate margin to establish the financial viability of the component. As sensitivity and risk 
analyses reveal that the financial internal rate of return is most sensitive to variation in revenue, 
timely tariff adjustments or government subsidies will be crucial to ensuring the financial viability 
and  sustainability  of  the  subcomponents.  Currently,  water  tariff  subsidies  are  provided  to

PRC processes for public participation will be followed for any tariff adjustments.  
 
20.  The  financial  management  assessment  conducted  for  the  implementing  agencies 
indicates that they have sufficient financial management capacity and project management 
experience but lack knowledge of ADB disbursement guidelines. The capacity development 
component will therefore provide on-the-job training on ADB policy and procedures  during 
project implementation.13  
 
C.  Governance 
21.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the DMG, ZMG, Ganzhou District government, PMOs, and project implementing agencies. 
Specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 
10). 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
22.  A poverty and social assessment during project preparation included a household survey, 
community and focus group discussions, and key informant interviews.14 As Gansu is one of the 
PRC’s  poorest  and  least-developed  western  provinces,  it  has  been  prioritized  in  national 
development plans. The project will directly benefit over 941,000 urban residents in the two 
cities, of whom 15.6% are poor, by improving living conditions, municipal services, the urban 
environment, and wetland ecology. The project will create an estimated 3,649 full-time jobs 
during construction and 535 during operation. Employment targets for vulnerable groups and 
women are included in the design and monitoring framework and loan assurances. Public health 
and  safety  will  benefit  from  improvements  to  the  urban  environment;  improved  traffic 
management  with  the  development  of  the  urban  road  network,  including  universal  design 
principles, and improvements in public transport and non-motorized transport and road safety; 
and wetland protection. A social development action plan has been prepared for implementing 
agencies to follow during project implementation. 
 
E.  Gender  
23.  The project is classified as effective gender mainstreaming. A gender action plan has 
been  prepared.  Data  from  survey  and  focus  group  discussions  reveal  that  women  are 
disproportionately affected by poor mobility and limited access to tap water because of their 
family and household responsibilities and employment in low-paying jobs. Improvements to the 
urban transport network and attention to the needs of women when planning public transport, 
access to pedestrian and non-motorized transport; and road safety programs will benefit women 
by reducing time and cost burdens and increasing access, mobility, and safety. Improvements 
to  wetlands,  attention  to  tourism  development,  awareness  building,  and  resulting  job 
opportunities will benefit women. The gender action plan includes specific targets for women in 
employment and participation in capacity-building opportunities, which are supported by a loan 
assurance and consultant support for implementation and monitoring.15

14  Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).  
15  Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
F.  Safeguards  
24.  Environment. The project is environment category A, primarily because of the Zhangye 
wetland protection component, which will support rehabilitation and protection activities in the 
experimental  zone  of  the  Zhangye  Hei  River  Wetland  National  Nature  Reserve.  An 
environmental impact assessment was prepared, circulated to the Board of Directors, and 
posted  on  the  ADB  website  on  2  March  2012.  It  complies  with  ADB's  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009). The project will have substantial environmental and socioeconomic benefits, 
restoring and protecting 1,400 ha of wetland habitat. Potential negative environmental impacts 
associated  with  the  project  have  been  identified,  and  adequate  mitigation  and  monitoring 
arrangements  have  been  incorporated  in  the  environmental  management  plan.  Potential 
adverse  impacts  during  construction  and  operation  include  soil  erosion  from  earthworks, 
recommended  alteration  of  a  legally  protected area, traffic  noise  in  some  sensitive  areas, 
potential  impact  of  the  water  supply  component,  significant  spoil  disposal,  community 
occupational  health  and  safety  risks  during  construction,  and  limited standard  construction 
impacts.  These  impacts  will  be  prevented  or  minimized  to  an  acceptable  degree  if  the 
environmental management plan is effectively implemented. The environmental management 
plan is supported by loan covenants and capacity development and institutional strengthening 
under the project. A system to manage water quality and wetlands will be developed to monitor 
the  ecological  status  of  wetlands.  As  the  executing  agency,  the  Gansu  provincial  finance 
department disclosed relevant environment information to affected people, and the results and 
findings of consultation were used to modify the environmental impact assessment and project 
design. Consultation and public participation will continue throughout project implementation, 
and  any  environmental  complaints  or  disputes  will  be  handled  by  the  grievance  redress 
mechanism established for the project. 
 
25.  Resettlement.  The  project  is  resettlement  category  A,  as  construction  will  require 
significant land acquisition and resettlement. The project will affect 62 village groups, 16 villages, 
2 towns, and 2 districts in the project cities. A total of 245.7  ha of land will be acquired 
permanently and 8 ha occupied temporarily during implementation, affecting 3,327 households 
with 12,264 members whose land will be acquired. Houses and other buildings totaling 215,829 
square meters of floor space will be demolished, which will affect 698 households with 2,527 
members and 51 enterprises or institutions. Resettlement plans have been prepared for the 
Dingxi and Zhangye urban infrastructure components, and a due diligence report has been 
prepared for the wetland protection component in Zhangye. Resettlement plans will be finalized 
based on the final design and detailed measurement survey, disclosed to affected people in the 
local language, and submitted to ADB for review and approval before civil works contracts are 
awarded. A grievance redress mechanism has been established for affected people. The PMOs 
will (i) submit internal monitoring reports semiannually to ADB and (ii) engage an external 
monitor to conduct baseline studies of affected people, verify the progress of land acquisition 
and resettlement, assess its impacts, and submit semiannual monitoring reports for ADB’s 
review during resettlement implementation and annually for 2 years after the completion of 
resettlement. 
 
26.  Indigenous peoples. The project is indigenous peoples category C. Ethnic minorities 
living in the project cities are well integrated economically and socially into the broader society. 
They will benefit equally from the project. No adverse impacts particular to ethnic minorities 
were identified.

10 
G.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
27.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and detailed in the risk 
assessment and risk management plan.16 The integrated benefits and impacts of the project are 
expected to outweigh the costs and risks. 
 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Difficulty in complying with Asian  Early mobilization of procurement agents and implementation 
Development Bank procedures  consultants to provide technical support combined with ongoing 
training

coordination meetings. Ensuring interagency coordination and timely 
completion of construction and construction supervision

approvals and implementation  early availability of compensation funding, and timely finalization and

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
28.  The  government  and  the  Gansu  provincial  government  have  assured  ADB  that 
implementation  of  the  project  shall  conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those 
concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and 
disbursement as described in detail in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
The government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth 
in the loan and project agreements. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
29.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$100,000,000  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  the  Gansu  Urban  Infrastructure 
Development  and  Wetland  Protection  Project  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  with 
interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-
based lending facility; for a term of 25 years, including a grace period of 5 years; and such other 
terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and 
project agreements presented to the Board. 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President
